title: The Illawarra siblings setting the A - League comps alight | Illawarra Mercury
body_text:
- Click here to follow our Whatsapp channel for the latest Illawarra news
Three sets of siblings highlight the growing number of Illawarra footballers making their mark in this season's A-League Men and Women competitions.
Subscribe now for unlimited access.
or signup to continue reading
The Bonetig brothers, Alex and Liam, are playing in the heart of the defence for their respective A-League teams, Western Sydney Wanderers and Melbourne City.
The Shellharbour juniors went head-to-head for the first time in their professional career when the Wanderers opened their 2025-26 campaign in October against the reigning champions Melbourne City at CommBank Stadium.
Alex, 23, has been a member of the Wanderers for more than a decade, rising through the academy ranks, while 20-year-old Liam recently returned home to Australia after a lengthy stint with Scottish giants Celtic FC.
The older Bonetig brother and his Wanderers will come up against another Shellharbour junior in Joel King this Saturday, in the latest instalment of the Sydney derby.
King has been a standout for ladder-leaders Sydney FC, who have won four games on the bounce heading into the CommBank Stadium clash against the Wanderers.
The left back's sister, Taren King, is also making her mark in the A-League Women competition.
The 28-year-old captain of the Central Coast Mariners has also played for fellow A-League women's outfits Canberra United (2017-20) and the Newcastle Jets (2020-23).
Joel King said the siblings supported each other during their football journey.
"Whenever I can, I like to go and watch my sister play. She obviously had a good season last year. They won the grand final. I was very happy for her," he said.
"She comes to watch me, and I go to watch her when I can. We're always there for each other."
The whole King family were in the Leichhardt Oval stands recently to watch Taren lead her Mariners into battle against Sydney FC.
"All of my family were there watching my sister versus Sydney on the weekend. It wasn't a great result for her, but for Sydney it was. I was happy Sydney won, but disappointed for her."
The 25-year-old has had plenty of reasons to be happy recently, playing a starring role in the first five rounds for the competition leaders, Sydney FC.
"I think I've been playing pretty well, obviously the results are going our way, so that helps a lot," King said.
"We've had a long pre-season, and I've done pretty well then, so I'm happy to keep my spot in the starting side.
"The last few games we've had a few wins. I think we're in a good spot at the moment, obviously a big game this weekend, and hopefully we can get another three points."
Sydney has seven competition points more than the ninth-placed Wanderers (5), but King knows you can throw form out the window whenever these two fierce derby rivals collide.
"The derbies are always different, they're always up for it, it's a form goes out the window type of game, so we're going to have to be up for it, and I'm sure we will be."
Joel King is not the only Illawarra-born or raised footballer playing for Sydney FC. The defender's teammates include Helensburgh Thistles junior Gus Hoefsloot (goalkeeper) and 19-year-old Dapto Lakeside Lions junior Zac De Jesus.
There are also several Illawarra connections in Sydney FC's women's team.
Wollongong-born Figtree FC junior Mackenzie Hawkesby has won multiple premierships and championships with Sydney FC.
The 25-year-old midfielder was named in the Sydney FC 20th Anniversary Team.
Fellow Figtree FC junior Caley Tallon-Henniker and Coledale Waves junior Sofia Fante also play for the Sky Blues.
Goalkeeper Fante is in the Young Matildas squad playing the Korea Republic in a two-match international friendly series at the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS) in Canberra this weekend.
More Illawarra sport:
Sydney FC's brightest young star is injured, Shellharbour junior Indiana Dos Santos.
The 18-year-old superstar is one of two Dos Santos sisters setting the A-League women's competition alight.
Her 20-year-old sibling, Jynaya, plays for the Central Coast Mariners. She joined the Mariners after a spell with Canberra United, where former Illawarra Stingrays and Matildas striker Michelle Heyman plays.
The list of Illawarra stars playing in the nation's top men's and women's competition also includes Phillip Cancar (Wanderers), Matthew Jurman (Macarthur FC), Walter Scott (Macarthur), Mile Sterjovski (Macarthur head coach) and Sienna Saveska (Melbourne Victory).
